transcripts.text: So I want to mention that oppression isn't just measured by wealth or misery because oppression involves barriers that reduce people.  into certain lifestyles.  So for Asian-Americans, for example, often, even at the school, they're seen as a model minority.  There's more societal pressure to succeed academically.  And that's also a cultural thing.
I'm saying you can't say racism doesn't exist in America because oppression still exists.

So give me an example of how that's racist, that the Asian mothers want their kids to go to college.  How's that racist?  How is it racist that Asian families put a lot of pressure on their kids to succeed?  There's nothing racist about that.
Well, okay, so being here at a wealthy, predominantly white school, just because you're non-white or even non-Christian, often you're, like, the assumption is you're here because of those qualities.

Okay, I would never make that judgment.  If someone does, then that is racism.  So I'm sorry that happens, but let me make a step further.  If you or someone else uses the term white privilege, that is equally as racist as someone making that value judgment against you.
